detaileddescription.para: Get the Butcher tableau.

detaileddescription.para: Set the Butcher tableau.
Project the ODEs system solution $ \mathbf{x} $ on the invariants $ \mathbf{h} (\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{v}, t) = \mathbf{0} $. The constrained minimization problem to be solved is:
Given the Lagrangian of the minimization problem of the form:
The solution of the problem is obtained by solving the following:
Using the Taylor expansion of the Lagrangian:
define the iterative method as:
Notice that $ \delta\mathbf{x} $ is the solution of the linear system:
where $ \mathbf{Jh}_\mathbf{x} $ is the Jacobian of the invariants/ with respect to the states $ \mathbf{x} $.

parameterdescription.para: The initial guess for the states $ \widetilde{\mathbf{x}} $.
The time $ t $ at which the states are evaluated.

simplesect.para: The solution of the projection problem $ \mathbf{x} $.

detaileddescription.para: Solve the system of ODEs/DAEs and calculate the approximate solution over the mesh of time points.

parameterdescription.para: Time mesh points $ \mathbf{t} = \left[ t_0, t_1, \ldots, t_n \right]^T $.

simplesect.para: A matrix $ \left[(\mathrm{size}(\mathbf{x}) \times \mathrm{size} (\mathbf{t})\right] $ containing the approximated solution $ \mathbf{x}(t) $ and $ \mathbf{x}^\prime(t) $ of the system of ODEs/DAEs.

memberdef.argsstring: (in this, in t, in x_0, in varargin)
memberdef.name: solve_adaptive_step

detaileddescription.para: Solve the system of ODEs/DAEs and calculate the approximate solution over the suggested mesh of time points.

parameterdescription.para: Time mesh points $ \mathbf{t} = \left[ t_0, t_1, \ldots, t_n \right]^T $.

simplesect.para: A matrix $ \left[(\mathrm{size}(\mathbf{x}) \times \mathrm{size} (\mathbf{t})\right] $ containing the approximated solution $ \mathbf{x}(t) $ and $ \mathbf{x}^\prime(t) $ of the system of ODEs/DAEs.

memberdef.argsstring: (in this, in x_k, in x_dot_k, in t_k, in d_t)
memberdef.name: advance

detaileddescription.para: Advance using a generic integration method for a system of ODEs/DAEs of the form $ \mathbf{F}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}', \mathbf{v}, t) = \mathbf{0} $. The step is based on the following formula:

where $ \mathcal{S} $ is the generic advancing step of the solver. In the advvancing step, the system of ODEs/DAEs is also projected on the manifold $ \mathcal{h}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{v}, t) $. Substepping is also used to ensure that the solution is accurate.

parameterdescription.para: States value at $ k $-th time step $ \mathbf{x}(t_k) $.
States derivative at $ k $-th time step $ \mathbf{x}' (t_k) $.

simplesect.para: The approximation of $ \mathbf{x_{k+1}}(t_{k}+\Delta t) $, $ \mathbf{x}'_{k+1}(t_{k}+\Delta t) $ and the suggested time step for the next advancing step $ \Delta t_{k+1} $.

memberdef.argsstring: (in this, in x_h, in x_l, in d_t)
memberdef.name: adapt_step

detaileddescription.para: Compute adaptive time step for the next advancing step according to the error control method. The error control method used is the local truncation error method, which is based on the following formula:

where $ \mathbf{x} $ is the approximation of the states at computed with higher order method of $ p $, and $ \hat{\mathbf{x}} $ is the approximation of the states at computed with lower order method of $ \hat{p} $. To compute the suggested time step for the next advancing step $ \Delta t_{k+1} $, The error is compared to $ 1 $ in order to find an optimal step size. From the error behaviour $ e \approx Ch^{q+1} $ and from $ 1 \approx Ch_{opt}^{q+1} $ (where $ q = \min(p,\hat{p}) $) the optimal step size is obtained as:

We multiply the previous quation by a safety factor $ f $, usually $ f = 0.8 $, $ 0.9 $, $ (0.25)^{1/(q+1)} $, or $ (0.38)^{1/(q+1)} $, so that the error will be acceptable the next time with high probability. Further, $ h $ is not allowed to increase nor to decrease too fast. So we put:

for the new step size. Then, if $ e \leq 1 $, the computed step is accepted and the solution is advanced to $ \mathbf{x} $ and a new step is tried with $ h_{new} $ as step size. Else, the step is rejected and the computations are repeated with the new step size $ h_{new} $. Typially, $ f $ is set in the interval $ [0.8, 0.9] $, $ f_{max} $ is set in the interval $ [1.5, 5] $, and $ f_{min} $ is set in the interval $ [0.1, 0.2] $.

parameterdescription.para: Approximation of the states at $ k+1 $-th time step $ \mathbf{x_{k+1}}(t_{k}+\Delta t) $ with higher order method.
Approximation of the states at $ k+1 $-th time step $ \mathbf{x_{k+1}}(t_{k}+\Delta t) $ with lower order method.

simplesect.para: The suggested time step for the next advancing step $ \Delta t_{k+1} $.

memberdef.argsstring: (in this, in x_k, in x_dot_k, in t_k, in d_t)
memberdef.name: step

detaileddescription.para: Compute a step using a generic integration method for a system of ODEs/DAEs of the form $ \mathbf{F}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}', \mathbf{v}, t) = \mathbf{0} $. The step is based on the following formula:
where $ \mathcal{S} $ is the generic advancing step of the solver.

parameterdescription.para: States value at $ k $-th time step $ \mathbf{x}(t_k) $.
States derivative at $ k $-th time step $ \mathbf{x}' (t_k) $.

simplesect.para: The approximation of $ \mathbf{x_{k+1}}(t_{k}+\Delta t) $ and $ \mathbf{x}'_{k+1}(t_{k}+\Delta t) $.

detaileddescription.para: Check Butcher tableau consistency for an explicit Runge-Kutta method.

simplesect.para: True if the Butcher tableau is consistent, false otherwise.

detaileddescription.para: Class container for Runge-Kutta solvers of the system of Ordinary Differential Equations (ODEs) or index-0 Differential Algebraic Equations (DAEs). The user must simply define the Butcher tableau of the solver, which defined as:
where $ \mathbf{A} $ is the Runge-Kutta matrix (lower triangular matrix):

para.formula: \[ \mathbf{A} = \begin{bmatrix} a_{11} & a_{12} & \dots & a_{1s} \\ a_{21} & a_{22} & \dots & a_{2s} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ a_{s1} & a_{s2} & \dots & a_{ss} \end{bmatrix}, \]

detaileddescription.para: $ \mathbf{b} $ is the Runge-Kutta weights vector relative to a method of order $ p $ (row vector):
$ \hat{\mathbf{b}} $ is the (optional) embedded Runge-Kutta weights vector relative to a method of order $ \hat{p} $ (usually $ \hat{p} = p1 $ or $ \hat{p} = p+1 $) (row vector):
and $ \mathbf{c} $ is the Runge-Kutta nodes vector (column vector):
